abstract.p: Alexander Kent letter replies to Philip Ball's July 1 Op-Ed article opposing human exploration of Mars

block.p: Philip Ball (Op-Ed, July 1) characterizes the proposed human exploration of Mars as a ''hubristic endeavor.'' Why is it hubristic for humans to put themselves on another planet? Because of the risk and the cost?

Philip Ball (Op-Ed, July 1) characterizes the proposed human exploration of Mars as a ''hubristic endeavor.'' Why is it hubristic for humans to put themselves on another planet? Because of the risk and the cost?

Humans have always roamed the face of the earth in defiance of risk and cost calculations. With results that have been and always will be decidedly mixed, humans have insisted on putting themselves where they have not been before. Our species moves, and there is nothing inherently wrong with that.

A venture is usually described as hubristic only when it fails. Let the explorers and scientists go to Mars and beyond with a sustained sense of purpose and prudence. Let NASA and the space agencies of other countries tap our basic and necessary human impulse to venture beyond perceived limits. Let's go.
ALEXANDER KENT Highland Park, N.J., July 1, 2000
